{{Infobox game | name=Friday Night at the ER Game | image=Hands_of_people_playing_Friday_Night_at_the_ER_training_game.jpeg | image_size=220 | caption= Friday Night at the ER game board | genre = Experiential learning | players= 4 per board, 4 to 200 total | ages = For any team that needs to improve performance, ages 16+ | setup_time = 5-10 minutes per board | playing_time= 75 minutes game play + 90 minutes debriefing | skills= No healthcare knowledge is needed
A program leader is recommended | website = http://fridaynightattheer.com | footnotes= }} '''Friday Night at the ER''' is an [[experiential learning|experiential team-learning]] game. Played on game boards at tables with four players per board, each gameplay session is followed by a detailed debriefing in which participants relate the [[simulation]] experience to their own work and gain insights for performance improvement. The game simulates the challenge of managing a hospital during a 24-hour period. Players perform distinct functions, but they come to realize that they also depend on one another. While the game was designed to teach [[systems thinking]], it has served diverse learning objectives across many industries and cultures. Each session includes 1.5 hours of game play followed by approximately 1.5 to 2 hours of debrief and discussion. ==Background== The Friday Night at the ER game was developed in 1992 by Breakthrough Learning, Inc., a consulting and training firm based in Morgan Hill, California.{{cite book | last=Senge | first=Peter M. | year=1994 | title=The Fifth Discipline Fieldbook | publisher=Crown Business Publishing | pages=541–542 | isbn=978-0385472562 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OnIMbEC0UdgC | accessdate=March 9, 2014}} Its initial purpose was to broadly teach people to think systemically, collaborating across functional boundaries to achieve system goals. The game's design objectives were: * to create an experiential learning tool that would engage people in a learning process; * to simulate and illustrate dynamics that are common to complex systems; and * to promote an understanding of key systems principles in a way that enables people to gain insight about their relevance. Since its initial release, the Friday Night at the ER game has found use for a broader range of learning objectives within diverse organizations. Demonstrating the universality of systems principles, the game is in use by service organizations, manufacturing companies, government agencies, academic institutions and others in at least 30 countries. ==History and development== A predecessor learning game, [[Beer Distribution Game|The Beer Distribution Game]], demonstrated effective team learning about the behavior of complex systems through an experiential activity. In 1990, [[Peter Senge]] published ''[[The Fifth Discipline]]'' {{cite book | last=Senge | first=Peter M. | year=1990 | title=The Fifth Discipline | publisher=Doubleday/Currency | isbn=0-385-26094-6 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bVZqAAAAMAAJ | accessdate=March 9, 2014}} and popularized systems thinking as a discipline essential to [[learning organizations]].{{citation needed|date=July 2014}} The Friday Night at the ER game has its origins in a business case that took place in 1990 at San Jose Medical Center, in [[San Jose, California]], where a persistent problem of decreasing capacity for emergency patients was resolved using a [[system dynamics]] study that included a simulation model of patient flow. {{cite book | last=O'Reilly | first=Kellie Wardman | year=1995 | title=Managing The Rapids, Stories from the Forefront of the Learning Organization | publisher=Pegasus Communications | isbn=1-883-82308-0 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8DqTL6Tf588C | accessdate=March 9, 2014}} A high-leverage intervention to resolve the problem required collaboration across departments to share nursing staff during times of peak emergency demand. In 1992, healthcare management consultant Bette Gardner created the Friday Night at the ER game, loosely based on that case, to teach management principles and the practice of systems thinking within healthcare and other organizations.Gardner, Bette; DeMello, Steve (July/August 1993).''"Transformational leadership. Systems thinking in action."'' ''Healthcare Forum Journal,'' 36(4):25-8. The game development process included a computer-based simulation model (using the [[IThink|IThink simulation modelling environment]]), {{cite book |last=Richmond |first=Barry |date=15 November 2004 |title=An Introduction to Systems Thinking with iThink |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=up6bOwAACAAJ |publisher=isee systems, inc. |isbn=978-0970492104 |accessdate=10 March 2014 }} populated with time-of-day, day-of-week hospital arrival rates, and other data from public and private sources. The game was [[pilot test]]ed with groups and presented at conferences starting in 1992. {{cite conference |title=''The Integration of Systems Thinking and TQM - The Next Step in Quality Improvement'' |first1=Bette |last1=Gardner |first2=Chet |last2=Harmer |date=16 September 1992 |conference=Bay Area Quality Improvement Network |conferenceurl= |location=Cupertino, California}} {{cite conference |title=''Friday Night at the ER: A Learning Game'' |first=Bette |last=Gardner |date=December 7, 1992 |conference=1992 National Forum on Quality Improvement in Health Care, Institute for Healthcare Improvement |conferenceurl=http://www.ihi.org/education/Conferences/Pages/default.aspx |location=Orlando, Florida }} {{cite conference |title=''Friday Night at the ER: A Systems Thinking Simulation'' |first1=Bette |last1=Gardner |first2=Joyce |last2=Reynolds |date=17 October 1993 |conference=1993 Organizational Development Network National Conference |conferenceurl=http://www.odnetwork.org/?page=PastConf |location= San Francisco, California }} {{cite conference |url= |title=''Systems Thinking: A New Approach to Quality Improvement and Healthcare Delivery'' |first=Bette |last=Gardner |date=11 May 1994 |conference=Health Research and Educational Trust of New Jersey Healthcare Education Seminar |location=Princeton, New Jersey}} {{cite conference |title=''Friday Night at the ER: A Team Learning Game'' |first=Bette |last=Gardner |date=16 November 1994 |conference=Systems Thinking in Action Conference, Pegasus Communications |location= San Francisco, California }} {{cite conference |url= |title=''Applied Systems Thinking with the Friday Night at the ER Game'' |first1=Rhoda |last1=Ryba |first2=Barbara |last2=Spreadbury |date=27 March 2006 |conference=2006 Congress on Healthcare Management, American College of Healthcare Executives }} In 1997, the Friday Night at the ER game was published in electronic form in ''Activating the Fifth Discipline'', a PC based multimedia education program {{cite video game |title=Activating The Fifth Discipline | developer=Peter M. Senge |publisher=The Learning Circle/Arthur Andersen |date=1997 |platform=[[Personal computer|PC]]}} . {{cite web |url=http://www.cipd.co.uk/pm/peoplemanagement/b/weblog/archive/2013/01/29/3487a-1999-09.aspx |title=Review: Activating the Fifth Discipline: Volume 1: "Mental Models and Systems Thinking" |last1=McHale |first1=Jo |date= 2 Sep 1999 |website=CIPD |publisher=CIPD |accessdate=9 March 2014}} {{cite web |url=http://www.worldcat.org/title/activating-the-fifth-discipline/oclc/222212571 |title=Activating the Fifth Discipline |website=OCLC WorldCat |publisher=OCLC |accessdate=9 March 2014}} Although the Friday Night at the ER game depicts a hospital based in the United States, it has been adopted and widely used as a team-learning tool both within the healthcare field {{cite journal | last = Schneider, MD | first = Sandra | last2 = Zwemer, MD, MBA | first2 = Frank | last3 = Doniger, MD | first3 = Andrew | last4 = Dick, MD | first4 = Robbin | last5 = Czaprinski | first5 = Tim | last6 = Davis, MD | first6 = Eric | date = November 2001 | title = ''Rochester, New York: A Decade of Emergency Department Overcrowding'' | url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1111/j.1553-2712.2001.tb01113.x | journal = Academic Emergency Medicine | publisher = Blackwell Publishing Ltd. | volume = 8 | issue = 11 | pages = 1044–1050 | doi = 10.1111/j.1553-2712.2001.tb01113.x | accessdate = 10 March 2014 }} {{cite journal | last = Dolansky, PhD, RN | first = Mary A. | last2 = Moore, PhD, RN, FAAN | first2 = Shirley M. | date = September 2013 | title = ''Quality and Safety Education for Nurses (QSEN): The Key is Systems Thinking'' | url = http://www.nursingworld.org/Quality-and-Safety-Education-for-Nurses.html | journal = The Online Journal of Issues in Nursing | publisher = American Nurses Association | volume = 18 | issue = 3 | accessdate = 25 March 2015 }} and beyond, finding use across diverse industries including other service organizations, manufacturing companies, government agencies, and academic institutions. The Friday Night at the ER game has been used for training in at least 30 countries.{{citation needed|date=July 2014}} In 2014, an updated version of the Friday Night at the ER game was released with modernized and upgraded game and support materials. {{cite web |url= http://www.fridaynightattheer.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/FNER_whatsnew.pdf |title=What’s New |publisher=Friday Night at the ER |format=PDF |access-date=7 June 2015}} Reports of the effectiveness of Friday Night at the ER are largely based on [[Likert scale|Likert]] surveys, testimonials and [[Net Promoter]] surveys. In 2018, educators at University of North Carolina at Greensboro published results of research in which students were assessed before and after using Friday Night at the ER. They concluded that the Friday Night at the ER activity is a useful teaching strategy for complex problem solving and application of systems thinking concepts.{{cite journal |title=Enhancing Systems Thinking for Undergraduate Nursing Students Using Friday Night at the ER |journal=Journal of Nursing Education |date=November 2018|last=Bacon |first=Cynthia Thornton |last2=Trent |first2=Peggy |last3=McCoy |first3=Thomas P. |volume=57 |issue=11 |pages=687-689 |doi=10.3928/01484834-20181022-11 |url=https://doi.org/10.3928/01484834-20181022-11 |accessdate=8 November 2018}} ==Program structure== Participants in a group (from 4 to 200 people) are assembled at tables equipped with game boards and associated materials. A program leader or coordinator provides verbal instructions; then participants play the game on their own for approximately one hour. The gameplay is followed by scoring to measure team performance. After a brief stretch break, participants reconvene for a debriefing. The debrief is facilitated by the program leader with a structured progression of discussion questions, reflection exercises, didactic presentation, and group tasks to bring to light key lessons of the experience, its relevance to the group and how participants will put lessons into practice after the program. The structure of the program may be varied. For example, the gameplay's 24-hour simulation may be conducted in two 12-hour segments with a short debrief or planning meeting in between segments. Another variation has groups playing in separate rooms with a slightly different instruction or game-board structure in each room so that behavior and results can be compared. In addition to variations in the gameplay, the structure and content of the debrief may be designed to teach either a narrow or broad purpose. The program generally requires 3.5 to 4 hours to complete the gameplay and debrief. ==Gameplay and scoring== At each four-person table, players each manage one of four departments in a hospital: Emergency, Surgery, Critical Care, and Step Down. The gameboard hospital is consolidated and simplified (relative to reality) to enable players to progress through a simulated 24 hours in just one hour. Each department contains spaces in which patients are treated by staff, and game cards determine new patient arrivals as well as “ready to exit” indicators for patients. The game board may be seen as a hybrid version of a [[System dynamics#stock and flow diagrams|stock-flow]] map or [[flow process chart|process-flow chart]]. Players’ management tasks include determining staffing levels, accepting internal patient transfers, and remaining open to additional patients or diverting new ambulance arrivals. Among the other details of the gameplay are “events” that occur (e.g., a doctor is late, a room is being renovated, a staff member goes home sick), requiring reaction and management by players. Demand rates in the gameplay, by hour, from mid-day Friday to mid-day Saturday, represent the typical pattern seen in hospitals. Emergency arrivals ramp up during Friday night (a time when people more often engage in risky behaviors that lead to emergencies); while arrivals to other departments in the hospital decrease as the weekend begins. A portion of Emergency arrivals flow through to other departments, so players experience the ripple effect of demand and the challenge of interdepartmental hand-offs. Consequences of player decisions in the gameplay are both local and systemic. The structure of the game board, role assignments and the accounting system influence players to focus on department performance; yet as the game progresses it becomes evident that the more one tries to optimize a part, the worse the system as a whole performs. During the gameplay, players keep track of certain data on paperwork forms at each department. Following the gameplay, individuals at each table contribute to calculating a team score that reflects the quality of service they delivered and financial performance. Teams scores are displayed to provide benchmarks and to enable participants to relate behavior to performance. ==Debriefing== A standard debrief to teach applied systems thinking is described in the Friday Night at the ER Guide for Program Leaders with presentation slides to support key points. The debrief includes team reflection exercises, guided group discussion, didactic presentation and group tasks. During the debrief, participants are guided to focus on collaboration, innovation and data-driven decision-making as key strategies necessary for successful system performance. These three strategies are examined and they are shown to be interdependent. Participants see that these three strategies produce excellent performance in the gameplay, and that the same applies to their real-world endeavors within organizations. While these three strategies are not new ideas to most participants, the question is posed in the debrief, “Why, then, don’t we routinely put these strategies into day-to-day practice?”—as they demonstrated in the gameplay and as seen in the real world? An axiom from the field of [[system dynamics]], “structure drives behavior,” is presented and participants are led through an exercise in which they examine how various structures within their organization may (unintentionally) inhibit desired behaviors. Numerous variations to the standard debrief have been reported. ==Uses== Typical objectives for use of the Friday Night at the ER game, settings in which it is used and reported outcomes are shown below. Examples of Objectives *Improve collaboration across business units. *Prepare groups for a major change initiative. *Introduce principles and methods of [[Systems Thinking]], [[Balanced Scorecard]]s, [[Lean Services|Lean]], [[Theory of Constraints]], [[Kaizen]], Process Improvement, [[Six Sigma]], [[Total Quality Management]], [[Agile management|Agile]] and other improvement disciplines. *Clarify success factors and support [[leadership development]] in areas such as [[teamwork]], [[customer satisfaction]], [[conflict management]], [[change management]]. *[[Team building]]. Examples of Settings *An early meeting of a new, cross-functional project team *Leadership development, strategic planning or team-building retreat *A training or education course *Orientation program for new employees Examples of Outcomes *Guiding principles for working together; improved ability to work together *New or heightened awareness about: **the need to collaborate, to share responsibility for organization performance **the presence of mental models and their impact on behavior and decision-making **the role of information and feedback in decision-making *Insight about the underlying structure in organizations that drives behavior and motivation for change *Personal insight about the effectiveness of one’s management and communication practices *Improved competence in applying a newly learned discipline ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{cite web |url = http://www.fridaynightattheer.com |title = Friday Night at the ER website |website = Friday Night at the ER |publisher = Breakthrough Learning, Inc. |accessdate = 9 March 2014 }} {{cite web | last = Tomczak | first = Aleksandra | title = ''Friday Night at the ER'' animated presentation | publisher = House of Skills | date = 5 August 2013 | url = http://prezi.com/m5okcqta81la/friday-night-at-the-er-english/ | accessdate = 9 March 2014 }} {{cite web | last = Umbehr | first = Josh | title = ''Board Game: Fright Night At The ER'' | publisher = Medgadget | date = 6 Feb 2008 | url = http://www.medgadget.com/2008/02/role_playing_in_the_er.html | accessdate = 9 March 2014 }} {{cite web | last = Linden | first = Russ | authorlink = | title =''Management Simulation: Friday Night at the ER©'' | url = http://russlinden.com/html/management_sim.htm | accessdate = 9 March 2014 }} {{cite web | title = Friday Night at the ER® A simulation that… | publisher = Fulcrum | url = http://888fulcrum.com/microleadership/experiential-learning/er/ | accessdate = 12 March 2014 }} {{cite web | last = Warshanna-Sparklin | first = Salma | title = Friday Night at the ER'' | publisher = Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health | url = http://www.jhsph.edu/news/stories/2015/friday-night-at-the-er.html | accessdate = 16 November 2015 }} {{cite web | last = O'Connor | first = Megan | title = Changing Organizational Culture through Gaming | publisher = University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill | url = http://cdr.lib.unc.edu/record/uuid:db11f6bf-c933-4c78-b71b-177830f62afc | accessdate = 25 April 2015 }} {{Cite journal | title = Health Care Change Agents: Interview with Bette Gardner, CEO and Founder, Breakthrough Learning | journal = Medical Training Magazine | volume = 6 | issue = 4 | pages = 10-12 | date = December 2017 }} {{Cite journal | last = Young, DNP, RN, CNE | first = Judith | title = Using a Role-Play Simulation Game to Promote Systems Thinking | journal = The Journal of Continuing Education in Nursing | volume = 49 | issue = 1 | pages = 10-11 | date = January 2018 | url = http://doi.org/10.3928/00220124-20180102-04 }} [[Category:Experiential learning]] [[Category:Simulation]] [[Category:Systems In [[bioethics]] and [[law]], '''gene theft''' or '''DNA theft''' is the act of acquiring the [[genetic material]] of another human being without his or her permission, often from a public place. The [[DNA]] may be harvested from a wide variety of common objects such as discarded cigarettes, used coffee cups, and hairbrushes. This genetic material can then be used for purposes such as establishing [[Paternity (law)|paternity]], proving [[genealogy|genealogical connections]] or even unmasking [[medical privacy|private medical]] conditions.<ref name="ReferenceA">Harmon, Amy. Stalking Strangers’ DNA to Fill in the Family Tree. ''The New York Times'' April 2, 2007</ref>
==Criminal law== [[Great Britain]] criminalized the acquisition of DNA without consent in 2006 at the urging of the [[Human Genetics Commission]].<ref>Womack, Sarah. [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1394939/Report-urges-ban-on-secret-DNA-tests.html Report urges ban on secret DNA tests], ''The Daily Telegraph'', May 22, 2002</ref><ref>Editorial: The Human Tissue Act, ''British Medical Journal'', Sept 9, 2006.</ref> Australia's legislature debated a two-year jail sentence for such theft in 2008.<ref>[http://www.upi.com/Top_News/2008/11/10/Australia-considers-DNA-theft-laws/UPI-44161226357348/ Australia considers DNA theft laws] United Press International, Nov 10, 2008</ref><ref>Smith, Deborah. Theft of DNA should be a crime: Experts, Sydney Morning Herald'', May 30, 2003</ref>
In the United States, eight states currently have criminal or civil prohibitions on such nonconsensual appropriation of genetic materials.<ref>Appel, Jacob M. [http://www.newhavenregister.com/articles/2009/11/05/opinion/doc4af258b842a6d983291505.txt 'Gene-nappers,’ like identity thieves, new threat of digital age], ''The New Haven Register'', Nov. 5, 2009</ref> In [[Alaska]], [[Florida]], [[New Jersey]], [[New York (state)|New York]] and [[Oregon]], individuals caught swiping DNA face fines or short jail sentences.<ref name="newhavenregister.com">Appel, Jacob M. [http://www.newhavenregister.com/articles/2009/11/05/opinion/doc4af258b842a6d983291505.txt 'Gene-nappers,’ like identity thieves, new threat of digital age], ''The New Haven Register'', Nov. 5, 2009</ref> Lawsuits against "gene snatchers" are permitted in [[Minnesota]], [[New Hampshire]] and [[New Mexico]].<ref name="newhavenregister.com"/> In jurisdictions where such nonconsentual taking of DNA is illegal, exceptions are generally made for law enforcement.
== Ethics == Many [[bioethics|bioethicists]] believe that such conduct is an unethical invasion of [[right to privacy|human privacy]].<ref name="newhavenregister.com"/> Professor [[Jacob M. Appel|Jacob Appel]] has warned that criminals may acquire the capability to copy DNA of innocent people and deposit it at crimes scenes, endangering the blameless and undermining a key tool of forensic investigation."<ref name="newhavenregister.com"/> However, others defend the appropriation of genetic material on the grounds that doing so may further human knowledge in productive ways<ref name="ReferenceA"/> One particularly controversial case which received widespread attention in the media was that of Derrell Teat, a wastewater coordinator, who sought to acquire without consent the DNA of a man who was allegedly the last male descendant of her great-great-great grandfather’s brother.<ref name="ReferenceA"/><ref>San Francisco Chronicle, April 8, 2007</ref> Another prominent case was a United States paternity suit involving film producer [[Steve Bing]] and billionaire investor [[Kirk Kerkorian]].<ref>Coghlan, Andy. [https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn2305-dna-theft-should-be-a-criminal-offence.html DNA theft should "be a criminal offence"], May 21, 2002</ref>
== See also == *[[Genetic testing]] *[[Genetic privacy]] *[[Bioethics]] *[[Forensic evidence|Forensic testing]]
== References == {{Reflist}}

{{notability|organizations|date=February 2016}} The '''Global Studies Consortium''' (GSC) is an international academic association of over 20 institutions of higher learning. It seeks to "promote and facilitate graduate teaching programs in [[global studies]] and to foster cooperation among them." <ref>[http://globalstudiesconsortium.org/info/by-laws By-Laws, Global Studies Consortium]</ref> That cooperation includes exchange of materials and development of methods to survey outcomes,<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=EOp0BQAAQBAJ&pg=PA374&lpg=PA374&dq=%22Global+Studies+Consortium%22+Tokyo&source=bl&ots=QeBuweU4Ql&sig=80G_Z7C6oucuBMYCq2jAel-63Lk&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiiwKbNivHKAhUDRCYKHarRCQg4ChDoAQhBMAc#v=onepage&q=%22Global%20Studies%20Consortium%22%20Tokyo&f=false Lena Bader, et al. "University of Graz and Other Eighteen Universities' Curricula for Global Studies: Comparisons and Improvements." in Leonid Grinin, et al. ''Globalistics and Globalization Studies: Theories, Research & Teaching''.] p. 374</ref> annual meetings, and a student exchange program. GSC deals only with graduate level programs, and there is no comparable association for undergraduate degree programs in global studies.<ref name="Encyclopedia">[[Mark Juergensmeyer]], "Global Studies," [https://books.google.com/books?id=wJB2AwAAQBAJ&pg=PA734&lpg=PA734&dq=%22Global+Studies+Consortium%22&source=bl&ots=-P_GEK06fn&sig=Lyw2TJhzs9yYtJlJhkANc1icEHo&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiEj_Dw99rKAhVCFj4KHd0nDSQQ6AEIUzAM#v=onepage&q=%22Global%20Studies%20Consortium%22&f=false pp. 727-737] in Helmut K. Anheier and Mark Juergensmeyer, eds. 2012. ''Encyclopedia of Global Studies''. SAGE Publications.</ref>
The GSC was founded at a meeting of representatives of university global studies programs held in February 2007 at the [[Orfalea Center for Global and International Studies]] of the [[University of California at Santa Barbara]].<ref>[http://www.global.ucsb.edu/orfaleacenter/consortium/index.html "Global Studies Consortium: A network of graduate teaching programs on global studies," Orfalea Center website] (accessed 2 February 2016)</ref> It has been influential in defining the new field of [[global studies]].<ref name="Encyclopedia" />
GSC is linked to ''global-e: A Global Studies Journal''.<ref>[http://global-ejournal.org/about-2/ "About global-e," global-e website] ''(accessed 12 Feb 2016)''</ref>
==Members== The member programs of the GSC<ref>[http://globalstudiesconsortium.org/programs "Member programs of the Global Studies Consortium" GSC website] ''(accessed 3 Feb 2016)''</ref> are listed by continent below:
===Africa=== * [[The American University in Cairo]] (Egypt), [http://globalstudiesconsortium.org/programs/american-university-in-cairo School of Global Affairs and Public Policy]
===Asia=== * [[Hanyang University]] (South Korea), [http://globalstudiesconsortium.org/programs/hanyang-university Research Institute of Comparative History and Culture; Graduate Program in Transnational Humanities] * [[Hitotsubashi University]] (Japan), [http://globalstudiesconsortium.org/programs/hitotsubashi-university Institute for the Study of Global Issues] * [[Shanghai University]] (China), [http://globalstudiesconsortium.org/programs/shanghai-university Center for Global Studies] * [[Shantou University]] (China), [http://globalstudiesconsortium.org/programs/shantou-university Center for Global Studies] * [[Sophia University]] (Japan), [http://globalstudiesconsortium.org/programs/sophia-university Graduate Program in Global Studies]
===Australia=== * [[RMIT University]] (Australia), [http://globalstudiesconsortium.org/programs/rmit-university School of Global Studies, Social Science and Planning] * [[Australian National University]] (Australia), [http://globalstudiesconsortium.org/programs/australian-national-university Master of Globalisation]
===Europe=== * [[Aarhus University]] (Denmark), [http://globalstudiesconsortium.org/programs/aarhus-university MA in International Studies] * [[Berlin Graduate School for Transnational Studies]] (Germany) ([http://globalstudiesconsortium.org/programs/berlin-graduate-school-for-transnational-studies information]) ** [[Free University of Berlin]] ** [[Hertie School of Governance]] ** [[Social Science Research Center Berlin]] * [[European Master]] (which is also part of the [[Erasmus Mundus]] program) ** [[University of Leipzig]] (Germany), Global and European Studies Institute ([http://globalstudiesconsortium.org/programs/european-master co-ordinating institution]) ** [[London School of Economics and Political Science]] (United Kingdom), Economic History Department ** [[Roskilde University]] (Denmark), Department of Society & Globalization ** [[University of Vienna]] (Austria), Department of History ** [[University of Wroclaw]] (Poland), Institute of International Studies * [[Ghent University]] (Belgium), [http://globalstudiesconsortium.org/programs/university-of-ghent Ghent Centre for Global Studies] * [[Lomonosov Moscow State University]] (Russia), [http://globalstudiesconsortium.org/programs/lomosonov-moscow-state-university Faculty of Global Processes] * [[University of Graz]] (Austria), [http://globalstudiesconsortium.org/programs/university-of-graz Master's program in Global Studies]
===North America=== * [[Arizona State University]] (US), [http://globalstudiesconsortium.org/programs/arizona-state-university School of Global Studies] * [[Rutgers University-Newark]] (US), [http://globalstudiesconsortium.org/programs/rutgers-the-state-university-of-new-jersey-newark Division of Global Affairs] * [[The New School]] (US), [http://globalstudiesconsortium.org/programs/the-new-school International Affairs and Global Perspectives] * [[University of California at Santa Barbara]] (US), [http://globalstudiesconsortium.org/programs/university-of-california-at-santa-barbara Global & International Studies Program] * [[University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign]] (US), [[Center for Global Studies]] * [[University of Minnesota]] (US), [http://globalstudiesconsortium.org/programs/university-of-minnesota Institute for Global Studies] * [[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill]] (US), [http://globalstudiesconsortium.org/programs/university-of-north-carolina-at-chapel-hill Curriculum in International and Area Studies] * [[University of Pittsburgh]] (US), [http://globalstudiesconsortium.org/programs/university-of-pittsburgh World History Center / Global Studies Center] * [[Wilfrid Laurier University]] (Canada), [http://globalstudiesconsortium.org/programs/wilfrid-laurier-university Global Studies]
==Student exchange program==
In 2014, GSC started an exchange program called Student Mobility Scheme.<ref>[http://globalstudiesconsortium.org/mobility "Student Mobility Scheme," GSC website] ''(accessed 26 February 2016)''</ref> As of 2016, four of the member institutions participate: American University in Cairo; Lomonosov Moscow State University; Shanghai University; and Sophia University.
==Meetings== The GSC has held meetings every year following the [http://globalstudiesconsortium.org/meetings/santa-barbara-2007 2007 workshop at UCSB] where it was founded:<ref>[http://globalstudiesconsortium.org/meetings "Meetings," GSC website] (accessed 11 Feb 2016)</ref> # [http://globalstudiesconsortium.org/meetings/tokyo-2008 Tokyo], hosted by Sophia University, 17-18 May 2008. (At this meeting participants identified [[Global studies#Characteristics of Global Studies|5 main characteristics]] of global studies.) # [http://globalstudiesconsortium.org/meetings/leipzig-2009 Leipzig], hosted by University of Leipzig, 17-18 October 2009 # [http://globalstudiesconsortium.org/meetings/santa-barbara-2010 Santa Barbara], hosted by University of California - Santa Barbara, 24-25 April 2010 # [http://globalstudiesconsortium.org/meetings/shanghai-2011 Shanghai], Hosted by Shanghai University, 17-18 June 2011 (This meeting was preceded by the China Forum on Global Studies.<ref>[http://cgs.shu.edu.cn/Eng/ShowNews.asp?ID=44 "The 4th Global Studies Consortium Annual Meeting & China Forum on Global Studies," Shanghai University Center for Global Studies, 1 July 2011]</ref>) # [http://globalstudiesconsortium.org/meetings/melbourne-2012 Melbourne], hosted by RMIT University, Melbourne, 14-17 June 2012 # [http://globalstudiesconsortium.org/meetings/moscow2013 Moscow], hosted by Moscow State University, 20-23 June 2013 # [http://globalstudiesconsortium.org/meetings/Roskilde-2014 Roskilde], hosted by Roskilde University, 18-22 June 2014<ref>[http://www.hsozkult.de/event/id/termine-25204 "Annual Meeting Global Studies Consortium," hsozkult.de/]</ref> # [http://globalstudiesconsortium.org/meetings/Cairo2015 Cairo], hosted by the School of Global Affairs at the American University in Cairo, 4-8 June 2015 # [http://globalstudiesconsortium.org/meetings/pittsburgh2016 Pittsburgh], hosted by the Global Studies Center and World History Center of the University of Pittsburgh, June 2016

[[File:HaddaGenius.JPG|thumb|right|The "Genius with flowers", Hadda, Gandhara. 2-3rd century CE. [[Musée Guimet]].]]
'''Haḍḍa''' ({{lang-ps|هډه}}) is a [[Greco-Buddhist]] archeological site located in the ancient region of [[Gandhara]], ten kilometers south of the city of [[Jalalabad]], in the [[Nangarhar Province]] of eastern [[Afghanistan]].
==Background== Some 23,000 Greco-Buddhist sculptures, both clay and plaster, were excavated in Hadda during the 1930s and the 1970s. The findings combine elements of [[Buddhism]] and [[Hellenistic civilization|Hellenism]] in an almost perfect Hellenistic style.
[[Image:HaddaBodhisattva.jpg|thumb|200px|left|The [[Bodhisattva]] and [[Chandeka]], Hadda, 5th century CE]] {{History of Afghanistan}} Although the style of the artifacts is typical of the late Hellenistic 2nd or 1st century BCE, the Hadda sculptures are usually dated (although with some uncertainty), to the 1st century CE or later (i.e. one or two centuries afterward). This discrepancy might be explained by a preservation of late Hellenistic styles for a few centuries in this part of the world. However it is possible that the artifacts actually were produced in the late Hellenistic period.
Given the antiquity of these sculptures and a technical refinement indicative of artists fully conversant with all the aspects of Greek sculpture, it has been suggested that Greek communities were directly involved in these realizations, and that "the area might be the cradle of incipient Buddhist sculpture in [[Indo-Greek]] style".<ref>John Boardman, ''The Diffusion of Classical Art in Antiquity'' ({{ISBN|0-691-03680-2}})</ref>
The style of many of the works at Hadda is highly Hellenistic, and can be compared to sculptures found at the [[Bassae|Temple of Apollo in Bassae, Greece]].
The [[toponym]] Hadda has its origins in [[Sanskrit]] haḍḍa n. m., "a bone", or, an unrecorded *haḍḍaka, adj., "(place) of bones". The former - if not a fossilized form - would have given rise to a Haḍḍ in the subsequent vernaculars of northern India (and in the [[Old Indic]] loans in modern Pashto). The latter would have given rise to the form ''Haḍḍa'' naturally and would well reflect the belief that Hadda housed a bone-relic of Buddha. The term haḍḍa is found as a loan in [[Pashto language|Pashto]] haḍḍ, n., id. and may reflect the linguistic influence of the original pre-Islamic population of the area.
==Works of art== A sculptural group excavated at the Hadda site of Tapa-i-Shotor represents [[Buddha]] surrounded by perfectly Hellenistic [[Herakles]] and [[Tyche]] holding a [[cornucopia]].<ref>[http://www.fao.org/afghanistan/Data/Mapsystem/Archeological_Sites/html/img/19.jpg See image] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120731041835/www.fao.org/afghanistan/Data/Mapsystem/Archeological_Sites/html/img/19.jpg |date=2012-07-31 }}</ref> The only adaptation of the Greek iconography is that Herakles holds the thunderbolt of [[Vajrapani]] rather than his usual club.
Other attendants to the Buddha have been excavated which display manifest Hellenistic styles, such as the "Genie au Fleur", today in Paris at the [[Guimet Museum]].<ref>[http://www.frontlineonnet.com/fl1906/19060665.jpg See image] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20130103001644/www.frontlineonnet.com/fl1906/19060665.jpg |date=2013-01-03 }}</ref>
==Buddhist scriptures== It is believed the oldest surviving Buddhist manuscripts-indeed the oldest surviving Indian manuscripts of any kind-were recovered around Hadda. Probably dating from around the 1st century CE, they were written on bark in [[Gāndhārī language|Gandhari]] using the [[Kharoṣṭhī]] script, and were unearthed in a clay pot bearing an inscription in the same language and script. They are part of the long-lost canon of the [[Sarvastivadin]] Sect that dominated [[Gandhara]] and was instrumental in Buddhism's spread into central and east Asia via the [[Silk Road]]. The manuscripts are now in the possession of the [[British Library]].
{{See also|Gandharan Buddhist texts}}
==Destruction== Hadda is said to have been almost entirely destroyed in the fighting during the civil war in [[Afghanistan]].
==Gallery== <gallery> Labit - Buddah méditant - Hadda Afghanistan - Art gréco-bouddhique D 69 2.jpg|Head of the Buddha, Hadda. Image:Indo-GreekBanquet.JPG|Greek clothes, [[amphora]]s, wine and music, 1st century CE, Hadda. Image:HaddaTypes.JPG|Portraits from Hadda, 3rd century CE. Image: GandharaScrolls.JPG|Decorative [[scroll]]s from Hadda. Image: GandharanAtlas.JPG|The Greek god [[atlas (mythology)|Atlas]], supporting a Buddhist monument, Hadda. Image:HaddaBuddha.JPG|Polychrome Buddha, 2nd century CE, Hadda. File:Hadda Buddha Portrait5.JPG|Young woman, 3-4th century, Hadda. File:Hadda laughing boy 008.jpg|"Laughing boy" from Hadda. Image:HaddaSculpture.jpg|A sculpture from Hadda, 3rd century CE. File:Afghanistan, stupa TK23, sito di hadda, monastero di tapa-kalan, IV-V sec.JPG|Stupa base. </gallery> There were also many works of art lost as a result of the civil war. One of the worst of the casualties was the loss of two statues. The Red Mountain range in Bamiyan that once housed two giant statues of the Buddha, on cliff faces, besides smaller structures of archaeological significance. The two big statues, dating back to the 5th or 6th century CE, were the largest of all Buddhist statues so far attested in the world. Only remnants of these statues were left behind.

Do not use both--> | begins = <!--2013 date {{start date|2013|07|21}} --> | ends = <!--2013 date {{end date|2013|07|23}} --> | prev = ISMB 2016 | next = ISMB/ECCB 2017 | frequency = Annually | location = [[Prague]], [[Czech Republic]] (2017) | years_active = {{age|1993|07|06}} | first = | last = | participants = | attendance = 2,000<ref name="Rost2012">{{cite journal|last=Rost|first=B. |author2=Gaasterland, T. |author3=Lengauer, T. |author4=Linial, M. |author5=Markel, S. |author6=Morrison McKay, B. J. |author7=Schneider, R. |author8=Horton, P. |author9=Kelso, J. |title=Paving the future: finding suitable ISMB venues|journal=Bioinformatics|date=13 July 2012|volume=28|issue=19|pages=2556–2559|doi=10.1093/bioinformatics/bts420 |pmid=22796959 |pmc=3463122}}</ref> | genre = | budget = | patron = | organised = <!--"organized=" also works--> Teresa Przytycka, [[Pierre Baldi]] (2016 chairs) | people = | member = [[International Society for Computational Biology]] | website = {{URL|https://www.iscb.org/ismbeccb2017}} | footnotes = }} '''Intelligent Systems for Molecular Biology''' ('''ISMB''') is an annual [[academic conference]] on the subjects of [[bioinformatics]] and [[computational biology]] organised by the [[International Society for Computational Biology]] (ISCB). The principal focus of the conference is on the development and application of advanced computational methods for biological problems. The conference has been held every year since 1993 and has grown to become one of the largest and most prestigious meetings in these fields, hosting over 2,000 delegates in 2004.<ref name="Rost2012" /><ref name="Linial2008">{{Cite journal | last1 = Linial | first1 = M. | last2 = Mesirov | first2 = J. P. | last3 = Morrison Mckay | first3 = B. J. | last4 = Rost | first4 = B. | title = ISMB 2008 Toronto | doi = 10.1371/journal.pcbi.1000094 | journal = PLoS Computational Biology | volume = 4 | issue = 6 | pages = e1000094 | year = 2008 | pmid = 18584023| pmc =2427177 }}</ref> From the first meeting, ISMB has been held in locations worldwide; since 2007, meetings have been located in Europe and North America in alternating years. Since 2004, European meetings have been held jointly with the [[European Conference on Computational Biology]] (ECCB).
The main ISMB conference is usually held over three days and consists of presentations, [[poster session]]s and [[keynote|keynote talks]]. Most presentations are given in multiple parallel tracks; however, keynote talks are presented in a single track and are chosen to reflect outstanding research in bioinformatics. Notable ISMB keynote speakers have included eight Nobel laureates. The recipients of the ISCB [[Overton Prize]] and [[ISCB Senior Scientist Awards|ISCB Accomplishment by a Senior Scientist Award]] are invited to give keynote talks as part of the programme. The proceedings of the conference are currently published by the journal ''[[Bioinformatics (journal)|Bioinformatics]]''.
==History== [[File:Larry hunter computer scientist.jpg|thumb|alt=A black and white portrait of Lawrence Hunter|[[Lawrence Hunter]], co-chair of the first ISMB conference.]]
===Early meetings=== The origins of the ISMB conference lie in a workshop for [[artificial intelligence]] researchers with an interest in [[molecular biology]] held in November 1991.<ref name="Gibson2012">{{cite journal|last=Gibson|first=Todd A.|title=The Roots of Bioinformatics in ISMB|journal=PLoS Computational Biology|volume=8|issue=8|pages=e1002679|doi=10.1371/journal.pcbi.1002679|pmid=22952443|pmc=3431341|year=2012}}</ref> The workshop was organised by [[United States of America|American]] researcher [[Lawrence Hunter]], then director of the Machine Learning Project at the United States [[National Institutes of Health]]'s [[United States National Library of Medicine|National Library of Medicine]] (NLM) in [[Bethesda, Maryland]].<ref name="Searls1994">{{cite journal|last=Searls|first=D.|author2=Shavlik, J. |author3=Hunter, L. |title=The First International Conference on Intelligent Systems for Molecular Biology|journal=AI Magazine|year=1994|volume=15|issue=1|pages=12–13|url=http://www.aaai.org/ojs/index.php/aimagazine/article/view/1082/1000|accessdate=16 September 2013}}</ref> A subsequent workshop on the same topic held in 1992, hosted by the NLM and the [[National Science Foundation]], made it clear that a regular international conference for the field was required. Such a conference would be dedicated to molecular biology as a rapidly emerging application of artificial intelligence.<ref name="about-ismb">{{cite web|title=About ISMB|url=http://www.iscb.org/about-ismb|work=www.iscb.org|publisher=[[International Society for Computational Biology|ISCB]]|accessdate=16 September 2013}}</ref> Having successfully applied for grants from [[Association for the Advancement of Artificial Intelligence|AAAI]], [[National Institutes of Health|NIH]] and the [[Office of Science#Biological and Environmental Research|Department of Energy Office of Health and Environmental Research]], the first ISMB conference was held in July 1993, at the NLM. The conference was chaired by Hunter, [[David Searls]] (research associate professor at [[Perelman School of Medicine at the University of Pennsylvania|University of Pennsylvania School of Medicine]]) and [[Jude Shavlik]] (assistant professor of computer science at [[University of Wisconsin–Madison]]) and attracted over 200 attendees from 13 countries,<ref name="Searls1994" /> submitting 69 scientific papers.<ref name=Gibson2012 />
The success of the first conference prompted the announcement of a second ISMB conference at the end of the meeting. ISMB 1994 was initially planned to be held in [[Seattle]]. However, a competing meeting forced ISMB to change venues at short notice. The conference was held at [[Stanford University]] in August 1994 and was organised by [[Russ Altman]], a research scientist at [[Stanford University School of Medicine]].<ref name=Gibson2012 /> To emphasise the international aspect of the conference, ISMB 1995 was held at [[Robinson College, Cambridge]]. ISMB 1995 also marked a shift in the focus of the conference. [[International Society for Computational Biology|ISCB]] Board member and Director of the [[Spanish National Bioinformatics Institute]] [[Alfonso Valencia]] has stated that, in 1995, "the conference changed from a computer science-based conference to a point where everyone realized that, if you want to make progress, there has to be more focus in biology."<ref name=Gibson2012 />
===Formation of ISCB and expansion=== ISMB 1997 was held in [[Halkidiki]], [[Greece]] and marked the foundation of the [[International Society for Computational Biology]] (ISCB).<ref name="about-ismb" /> ISCB was formed with a focus on managing all scientific, organizational and financial aspects of the ISMB conference and to provide a forum for scientists to address the emerging role of computers in the biological sciences. ISCB has assisted in organising the ISMB conference series since 1998.<ref name="Linial2008" /> The period following the formation of ISCB also marked an expansion in the number of ISMB attendees: ISMB 2000 (held at the [[University of California, San Diego]]) was attended by over 1,000 delegates,<ref name="Rost2012" /> submitting 141 scientific papers.<ref name="Gibson2012" /> This meeting was also the last time ISMB would be held at a university, due to size limitations.<ref name="Rost2012" />
===Partnership with ECCB=== [[File:Wfm secc front.jpg|thumb|alt=The entrance to the Scottish Exhibition and Conference Centre|The first joint conference with [[European Conference on Computational Biology|ECCB]] was held in 2004 at the [[Scottish Exhibition and Conference Centre]].]] In 2004, ISMB was jointly held with the [[European Conference on Computational Biology]] for the first time. The conference was also co-located with the Genes, Proteins and Computers conference. This meeting, held in [[Glasgow]], [[UK]], was the largest [[bioinformatics]] conference ever held,<ref name=iscb-history>{{cite web|title=History of ISCB|url=http://www.iscb.org/iscb-history|work=www.iscb.org|accessdate=19 September 2013}}</ref> attended by 2,136 delegates, submitting 496 scientific papers.<ref name=ismbeccb2004>{{cite web|title=ISMB/ECCB 2004|url=http://www.iscb.org/cms_addon/conferences/ismbeccb2004/|accessdate=19 September 2013}}</ref> Alfonso Valencia considers ISMB/ECCB 2004 to be an important milestone in the history of ISMB: "it was the first one where the balance between Europe and the States became an important part of the conference. It was here that we established the rules and the ways and the spirit of collaboration between the Americans and the Europeans."<ref name="Gibson2012" /> The success of the joint conference paved the way for future European ISMB meetings to be held jointly with ECCB.<ref name="Gibson2012" />
===Recent meetings=== By the end of 2006, ISCB was in financial difficulty. Two conferences (ISMB 2003, in [[Brisbane]] and ISMB 2006, in [[Fortaleza]]) had drastically reduced numbers of participants due to their location, with a corresponding reduction in income.<ref name="Rost2013">{{cite journal|last=Rost|first=B.|title=ISCB: past-present perspective for the International Society for Computational Biology|journal=Bioinformatics|date=14 November 2013|doi=10.1093/bioinformatics/btt629|pmid=24234004|pmc=5994947|volume=29|issue=24|pages=3243–3245}}</ref> To allow more delegates to attend, it was decided to limit conference locations to North America and Europe. In January 2007, ISMB and ECCB agreed to hold joint conferences in Europe every other year, beginning with ISMB/ECCB 2007.<ref name="Linial2008" /> ISMB would be held in North America in the years between joint meetings. {{As of|2016}}, this pattern has been confirmed to continue until at least 2019. ISMB/ECCB 2007 (held in [[Vienna]], [[Austria]]) marked the first conference for which ISCB took full responsibility for organising.<ref name="Rost2012" /> Vienna became the first city to host ISMB twice with ISMB/ECCB 2011. This 'return visit' was an experiment intended to reduce the increasing effort required to find suitable conference venues. Although the return to Vienna was only deemed partially successful due to price increases, [[Boston]] (which hosted ISMB 2010 and 2014) is predicted to become a 'safe' site which ISMB can periodically return to.<ref name="Rost2012" />
ISMB celebrated its 20th meeting with ISMB 2012, held in [[Long Beach, California]]. This event attracted around 1,600 delegates,<ref name="Rost2012" /> submitting 268 scientific papers.<ref name="Gibson2012" /> Richard H. Lathrop and Lawrence Hunter presented a special keynote presentation, looking back at previous ISMB meetings and attempting to predict where the field of [[bioinformatics]] may head in the future.<ref name=ismb2012>{{cite web|title=Keynotes|url=http://www.iscb.org/ismb2012-program/ismb2012-keynotes|work=ISMB 2012|publisher=[[International Society for Computational Biology|ISCB]]|accessdate=26 August 2013}}</ref> ISMB/ECCB 2013 was held in [[Berlin]], [[Germany]] and was attended by around 2,000 delegates, submitting 233 scientific papers.<ref name="Ben-Tal2013">{{cite journal|last=Ben-Tal|first=N.|title=Editorial|journal=Bioinformatics|date=21 June 2013|volume=29|issue=13|pages=i1–i2|doi=10.1093/bioinformatics/btt282|pmid=23812973|pmc=3694647}}</ref>
==Format==
===Main conference=== The main ISMB conference is usually held over three days and consists of presentations, [[poster session]]s and [[keynote|keynote talks]].<ref name="Rost2012" />
[[Academic paper]]s at ISMB were traditionally presented in a single track.<ref name="Gibson2012" /> Presentations at ISMB 1994 were split further into three themed days, focusing on [[Protein structure prediction#Secondary structure|protein secondary structure prediction]], [[sequence analysis]] and AI techniques and biochemical applications, respectively.<ref name="Searls1994" /> As attendance at ISMB increased, the single track approach became increasingly unsustainable and two parallel tracks were introduced at ISMB/ECCB 2004. Further expansion meant that, by ISMB 2012, over 200 talks were presented in nine parallel tracks<ref name="Rost2012" /> including multiple [[proceedings]] tracks, a highlights track and a technology track. The introduction of parallel tracks to ISMB was controversial. [[Christopher Rawlings]] (head of Computational and Systems Biology at [[Rothamsted Research]] and organiser of ISMB 1995) has said: "There were a lot of people who wanted to keep it more strongly in the AI intelligent systems model and have a meeting where everybody would go to everything. But it just grew too big. We just couldn’t."<ref name="Gibson2012" /> As the number of submitted [[proceedings]] papers has increased, the acceptance rate has decreased dramatically, from 75% in 1994 to 13% in 2012.<ref name="Gibson2012" /> ISMB proceedings from 1993-2000 were published by [[AAAI Press]]. Since ISMB 2001, proceedings have been published in the journal ''[[Bioinformatics (journal)|Bioinformatics]]''.<ref>{{cite web|title=ISMB Proceedings|url=http://www.iscb.org/ismb-proceedings|work=www.iscb.org|publisher=[[International Society for Computational Biology|ISCB]]|accessdate=3 October 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Brunak|first=S.|author2=Krogh, A.|title=ISMB 2001|journal=Bioinformatics|date=1 June 2001|volume=17|issue=Suppl 1|pages=S1–S4|doi=10.1093/bioinformatics/17.suppl_1.S1}}</ref> The number of posters presented at ISMB has also increased dramatically. 25 posters were presented at ISMB 1994;<ref name="Searls1994" /> at recent ISMB meetings, 500-1,000 posters have been presented in multiple poster sessions.<ref name="Rost2012" />
[[File:Gunnar von Heijne ISMB 2012 (7803463978).jpg|thumb|left|alt=Gunnar von Heijne|[[ISCB Senior Scientist Awards|ISCB Accomplishment by a Senior Scientist Award]] winner [[Gunnar von Heijne]] giving his keynote talk at ISMB 2012.]] [[Keynote|Keynote talks]] are presented in a single track and generally attract the largest audience.<ref name="Linial2008" /> These presentations are chosen to highlight outstanding research in the field of [[bioinformatics]]. Notable [[List of Intelligent Systems for Molecular Biology keynote speakers|ISMB keynote speakers]] have included eight [[Nobel Prize|Nobel laureates]]: [[Richard J. Roberts]] (keynote speaker in 1994, 2006), [[John Sulston]] (1995), [[Manfred Eigen]] (1999), [[Gerald Edelman]] (2000), [[Sydney Brenner]] (2003), [[Kurt Wüthrich]] (2006), [[Robert Huber]] (2006) and [[Michael Levitt]] (2015).<ref name=about-ismb /><ref name=Neshich2006>{{cite journal|last=Neshich|first=Goran|author2=Bourne, Philip E. |author3=Brunak, Søren |title=ISMB 2006|journal=PLoS Computational Biology|date=1 January 2006|volume=2|issue=2|pages=e11|doi=10.1371/journal.pcbi.0020011|pmid=16758006|pmc=1378106}}</ref><ref name=ismb2015keynotes>{{cite web|title=Keynotes|url=http://www.iscb.org/ismbeccb2015-program/ismbeccb2015-keynotes|work=ISMB/ECCB 2015|publisher=ISCB|accessdate=18 May 2015}}</ref>
As of 2012, ISMB runs on a budget in excess of $1.5M and, in terms of proceeds, brings in four times that of the other ISCB conferences (ISCB-Latin America, [[ISCB Africa ASBCB Bioinformatics Conference|ISCB-Africa]], ISCB-Asia, Rocky Mountain Bioinformatics Conference, [[CSHALS]] and the Great Lakes Bioinformatics Conference) combined.<ref name="Rost2012" /> Standard registration fees (as of 2013) are around $1,000 for academics who are ISCB members ($1,350 for non-members), with lower rates for students and higher rates for corporate delegates respectively. Discounts are provided for early registration.<ref>{{cite web|title=REGISTER|url=http://www.iscb.org/ismbeccb2013-registration#registrationfee|work=ISMB/ECCB 2013|publisher=[[International Society for Computational Biology|ISCB]]|accessdate=25 October 2013}}</ref>
===Satellite events=== Pre-conference tutorials have played an important role in ISMB since the first conference.<ref name="Linial2008" /> Tutorials at ISMB 1994 included introductions to [[genetic algorithms]], [[neural networks]], [[artificial intelligence|AI]] for molecular biologists and [[molecular biology]] for computer scientists.<ref name="Searls1994" /> Tutorials on computational [[mass spectrometry]]-based [[proteomics]] and [[ENCODE]] data access were presented at ISMB/ECCB 2013.<ref name=iscbeccb2013-tutorials>{{cite web|title=Tutorials|url=http://www.iscb.org/ismbeccb2013-program/ismbeccb2013-tutorials|work=ISMB/ECCB 2013|publisher=[[International Society for Computational Biology|ISCB]]|accessdate=26 September 2013}}</ref>
As attendance at ISMB grew in the late 1990s, several satellite meetings and special interest group (SIG) meetings formed alongside the main conference. SIG meetings are held over one or two days before the main conference and focus on a specific topic, allowing more detailed discussion than there would be time for in the main conference.<ref name=ismbeccb2013-sigs>{{cite web|title=SIGs & Satellite Meetings|url=http://www.iscb.org/ismbeccb2013-program/ismbeccb2013-satellite-meetings|work=ISMB/ECCB 2013|publisher=[[International Society for Computational Biology|ISCB]]|accessdate=26 September 2013}}</ref> Notable SIG meetings include the [[Bioinformatics Open Source Conference]] (BOSC), which has been held annually since 2000<ref name=bosc>{{cite web|title=BOSC - Open Bioinformatics Foundation|url=http://www.open-bio.org/wiki/Past_BOSC_conferences |publisher=[[Open Bioinformatics Foundation]]|accessdate=26 September 2013}}</ref> and Bio-Ontologies, which has been held annually since 1998.<ref>{{cite journal|author-last1=Bodenreider|author-first1=Olivier|author-last2=Stevens|author-first2=Robert|title=Bio-ontologies: current trends and future directions|journal=Briefings in Bioinformatics|volume=7|issue=3|pages=256–274|doi=10.1093/bib/bbl027|pmid=16899495|pmc=1847325|year=2006}}</ref> Satellite meetings are usually two days long and are held in conjunction with ISMB. The 12th CAMDA conference and the 9th 3DSIG meeting were held as satellite meetings of ISMB/ECCB 2013.<ref name=3dsig-2013>{{cite web|title=3DSIG 2013 - Structural Bioinformatics and Computational Biophysics, Berlin 2013|url=http://bcb.med.usherbrooke.ca/3dsig13/|work=3DSIG 2013|accessdate=26 September 2013}}</ref><ref name=camda-2013>{{cite web|title=CAMDA 2013 Conference - CAMDA 2013|url=http://dokuwiki.bioinf.jku.at/doku.php|work=CAMDA 2013|accessdate=26 September 2013}}</ref>

The '''International Medical Education Directory''' ('''IMED''') was a public database of worldwide [[medical schools]]. The IMED was published as a joint collaboration of the [[Educational Commission for Foreign Medical Graduates]] (ECFMG) and the [[Foundation for Advancement of International Medical Education and Research]] (FAIMER).<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.wdoms.org/about/|title=World Directory of Medical Schools {{!}} About|website=www.wdoms.org|language=en|access-date=2017-04-13}}</ref>
The information available in IMED was derived from data collected by the [[Educational Commission for Foreign Medical Graduates]] (ECFMG) throughout its history of evaluating the medical education credentials of international medical graduates. Using these data as a starting point, [[Foundation for Advancement of International Medical Education and Research]] (FAIMER) began developing ''IMED'' in 2001 and made it publicly available in April 2002.<ref name=":0" />
In April 2014, IMED was merged with the [[Avicenna Directories|Avicenna Directory]] to create the [[World Directory of Medical Schools]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.faimer.org/resources/world-directory.html|title=FAIMER {{!}} World Directory of Medical Schools|website=www.faimer.org|language=en|access-date=2017-04-13}}</ref> The World Directory is now the definitive list of medical schools in the world, as IMED and [[Avicenna Directories|Avicenna]] were discontinued in 2015.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.faimer.org/news/2015/04/international-medical-education-directory-imed-discontinued-mid-2015/|title=International Medical Education Directory (IMED) To Be Discontinued by Mid-2015|last=|first=|date=|website=www.faimer.org|language=en|access-date=2017-04-13}}</ref>

[[Kathmandu University]] |type = [[Private university|Private]], Highly Profitable Company |principal = |website = [http://www.kcm.edu.np/ www.kcm.edu.np] }} '''Kathmandu College of Management''', popularly known as KCM, is a college of higher education located in Gwarko, [[Patan, Lalitpur|Lalitpur]], [[Nepal]]. KCM is the first management college to introduce BBA program in Nepal. It is affiliated to [[Siam University]] as well as [[Kathmandu University]] and is considered one of the premier management schools in Nepal. KCM provides bachelor's degrees in [[Administration (business)|Business administration]] ([[Bachelor of Business Administration|BBA]]) specializing in Marketing or Insurance and Finance. The college also provides professional training in [[MCSE]] and [[CCNA]]. ==External links== *[http://www.kcm.edu.np Kathmandu College of Management] *[http://www.inter.siam.edu Siam University] {{coord missing|Nepal}} KCM is also the only authorized test center for GMAT in Nepal. {{citation needed|date=March 2017}} [[Category:Universities and colleges in Nepal]] [[Category:Business schools]] {{Nepal-university-stub}}

The '''Modern Architectural Research Group''', or '''MARS Group''', was a [[United Kingdom|British]] [[architecture|architectural]] think tank founded in 1933 by several prominent architects and architectural critics of the time involved in the British [[International style (architecture)|modernist movement]]. The MARS Group came after several previous but unsuccessful attempts at creating an organization to support modernist architects in Britain such as those that had been formed on continental Europe, like the Union des Artistes Modernes in [[France]].
The group first formed when [[Sigfried Giedion]] of the [[Congrès International d'Architecture Moderne]] asked [[Morton Shand]] to assemble a group that would represent Britain at their events. Shand, along with [[Wells Coates]], chose [[Maxwell Fry]] and [[F. R. S. Yorke]] as the founding members. They were also joined by a few members of [[Tecton]], another architectural group, by [[Ove Arup]] and by [[John Betjeman]], a poet and contributor to ''[[Architectural Review]]''. The group's greatest success came in 1938 with a show at the New Burlington Galleries, but it also unfortunately left them in debt. The MARS group proposed a radical plan for the redevelopment of postwar London, the details of which were published the Architectural Review in 1942.<ref name="odnb01">http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/60598, accessed 27 Dec 2008. Charlotte Benton. 2004. 'Korn, Arthur (1891–1978)’ in ''Oxford Dictionary of National Biography''. Oxford: Oxford University Press.</ref> At its height there were about 58 members in the group.The group itself began to lose steam along with the movement and many members left as a result of creative differences. The group finally disbanded in 1957.
==The MARS Plan for London==
:"The plan for London issued by the Mars Group (the English wing of CIAM) and prepared by their Town Planning Committee was a marked contrast to anything that had gone before and, one might add, anything produced subsequently. It was frankly [[Utopian]] and Socialistic in concept." Dennis Sharp, 1971.<ref name="sharp01"/>
The plan was devised by what has been described as a 'small and devoted' group, under the town planning sub committee of MARS, chaired by [[Arthur Korn (architect)|Arthur Korn]], and including Arthur Ling, [[Maxwell Fry]], the latter who worked as secretary, and fellow Jewish emigre, engineer [[Felix Samuely]].<ref name="fry01">Pp 165-6 ''in'' Fry E. M. 1971, ' The MARS Group plan of London ''in'' Arthur Korn, [[Maxwell Fry]], [[Dennis Sharp]]. 1971. The M.A.R.S. Plan for London. ''Perspecta, Vol. 13 (1971), pp. 163-173''</ref> Arthur Korn is described as having been 'the main spring of the enterprise' and as providing an 'infectious enthusiasm' that drove the project forward.<ref name="fry01"/><ref name="gold01">P.88 ''in'' Gold J. R. 2000. 'Towards the functional city? MARS, CIAM and the London plans 1933-42. ''In'' Thomas Deckker, ''The Modern City Revisited''. Oxford: Taylor and Francis.</ref> Influenced by the Soviet urbanist Miliutin, the plan essentially conceived the centre of the city remaining much the same but with a series of linear forms or tongues extending from the Thames, described as like a herring bone, composed of social units and based around the rail network.<ref name="sharp01">P. 167 ''in'' Sharp S. 1971. 'Concept and Interpretation The aims and principles of the MARS plan for London'. ''In ''Arthur Korn, Maxwell Fry, Dennis Sharp. 1971. The M.A.R.S. Plan for London. ''Perspecta, Vol. 13 (1971), pp. 163-173''</ref><ref name="moughtin01">p122 ''in'' Moughtin J.C. and Shirley P. 1995. ''Urban Design: Green Dimensions''. Oxford: Architectural Press.</ref> Habitation in each social unit was to consist mainly of flats and owed much to [[Le Corbusier]]'s notion of the [[Unite d'Habitation|''unite d'habitation'']].<ref name="moughtin01"/> Described as 'unworkable' by [[Dennis Sharp]], in his 1971 essay on the plan, he concedes it 'was not a concrete scheme but a concept that would by its very nature produce interpretations'.<ref name="sharp01"/> Marmaras and Sutcliffe argue the plan 'saw London almost entirely in terms of movement ...[being] presented primarily as a centre of exchange and communications'.<ref name="marmaras01">Pp. 434-40 ''in'' Marmaras E. and Sutcliffe A. 1994. Planning for post-war London: the three independent plans, 1942-3. ''In'' ''Planning Perspectives, 9, (1994) 431-453''.</ref> Moughtin and Shirley (1995) note that one of the aims of the plan was to promote public transport, where with railways integral to planning, the 'need for cars will be few'. .<ref name="moughtin01"/><ref name="korn01">A. Korn and F.J. Samuely, A master plan for London,'' Architectural Review, 91, January (1942). 143–150.''</ref> Korn's initial chairmanship of the plan was interrupted by his 18-month internment in the [[Isle of Man]] from 1939, being a German citizen, during which period work on the plan fizzled out.<ref name="fry01"/> On his release, in 1941, work recommenced, an exhibition of the plan was organised and a 'description and analysis' was published under the joint authorship of Arthur Korn and Felix Samuely in the Architectural Association journal in 1942.<ref name="fry01"/><ref name="marmaras01"/>
